title: https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16183

last_post.content:
See paper for more results+discussion. Two quick points:
1) These results may have interesting implications for “agency.”
2) These results *certainly* do not imply that passive learning is better than active (cf. https://twitter.com/hausman_k/status/1661037780049494017?s=20), or that confounding is not a problem.

Thanks for making it through this thread! And thanks to my co-authors:
@scychan_brains , Ishita Dasgupta,
Andrew Nam, and Jane Wang
(but any mistakes are no doubt mine). Paper link again: https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.16183 7/7

I'm impressed. Google created a refreshing implementation of generative AI to search.

I don't know how practical it will be, but I am pleasantly surprised so far

title: https://calckey.social/tags/Barcelona

last_post.content:
How will defederating prevent Meta from gathering data? Google doesn’t even have an official Fediverse server and they gather data. You can see all they gather through a mere search.

Even without ActivityPub, Meta can gather data. They can just collect via RSS if they want. So much content is out there in the open.

Here’s the scary thing about Meta. You don’t need to have an account for them to track you. They can build shadow profiles on you based on pixels.

This is the reality.

That said, people who use Meta products would be better off Meta, and they need a way to migrate away.

I’m not saying anyone should federate with Meta. That’s not what I’m suggesting.

But what needs to happen, though, is that folks who are on #Barcelona realize there’s a greater Fediverse that they can access—which would ideally be the catalyst to leave Meta-owned services.

How to do this? I don’t know. And this is in part because we don’t yet entirely know what Barcelona will be.

RE: https://mstdn.patatas.ca/users/smallpatatas/statuses/110432897559593466

title: Programming with Natural Language Is Actually Going to Work—Stephen Wolfram Writings

last_post.content: Mathematical syntax was invented because the human language was too ambiguous and clumsy to communicate ideas that needed precision, for the same reason we invented programming languages. Now, we're doing the full circle and we want to use human language. I wonder how long we need to figure out again that it is *more* complicated to communicate some ideas in human language vs domain-specific languages. https://writings.stephenwolfram.com/2010/11/programming-with-natural-language-is-actually-going-to-work/

title: Carl T. Bergstrom (@ct_bergstrom@fediscience.org)

last_post.content:
"The only knowledge it has is knowledge of distribution of linguistic form."

From: @ct_bergstrom
https://fediscience.org/@ct_bergstrom/110427799941264974

There's a lot of discussion about bias in terms of gender, race, ethnicity etc., but what do we actually mean by bias?

The notion of bias is often discussed informally, also in academic literature, leading to imprecise discussions and potentially to misguided policy recommendations, which may even have adverse effects.

@vtraag and I propose a more systematic way of studying biases https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/impactofsocialsciences/2023/05/25/the-bias-puzzle-understanding-gender-differences-in-academia/.

Our #LSE blog post is based on a preprint published last year https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2207.13665.

title: Operationalizing Counterfactual Metrics: Incentives, Ranking, and Information Asymmetry

last_post.content:
Theoretical analysis of #MachineLearning decision making. #Fairness viewed as #SocialWelfare should also take into account the alternative decision (called #counterfactual outcomes). This paper proposes a framework which models two kinds of actors: (1) a "principal" who is the central organisation; (2) a set of "agents" who provides the service under consideration. The social welfare goal is to design reward functions with high utility for the principal.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2305.14595

title: The bias puzzle – Understanding gender differences in academia

last_post.content:
Nature recently introduced new guidelines for studies engaging with questions of race, ethnicity or gender. Among others, it asks researchers to explain how they controlled for #confounding variables. We agree this is important, especially because we think #bias and #disparity should be understood in #causal terms. In this #LSE impact blog, @LudoWaltman and I discuss some of the challenges around this.

https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/impactofsocialsciences/2023/05/25/the-bias-puzzle-understanding-gender-differences-in-academia/

title: https://tinyurl.com/dighis23-grallert

last_post.content:
I thoroughly enjoyed presenting my data-driven research on late Ottoman #Arabic #Periodicals at #DigHis23. The paper introduces stylometric authorship attribution for answering the question whether editors/publishers of magazines could or should be considered the authors of the bulk of anonymous texts in their periodicals. The method relies on collaborative work with Maxim Romanov on establishing parameters for reliable authorship attribution in Arabic for the `stylo()` package in #R (#Rstats).

Slides are available at https://tinyurl.com/dighis23-grallert

#MultilingualDH #DigitalHumanities #DigitalHistory #PeriodicalStudies #Stylometry

last_post.content:
The United States has a #DebtCeiling because in 1917, Congress would have had to gather slowly by train and horse-and-buggy to approve new debt to pay for World War I. An economist points out that other countries do fine without this archaic law:

“The best solution would be to scrap the debt ceiling altogether. Congress already approved the spending and the tax laws that require more debt. Why should it also have to approve the additional borrowing?”
